normalised: Hey folks, let's talk about something that's probably made you yell at your inverter more than once: load shedding! Or, as my Dadi in Lucknow calls it, "bijli gul." We're talking about those planned power outages, usually because the electricity grid can't handle the demand, especially during those scorching Delhi summers.

normalised: It's a bit like when everyone in your family tries to stream Netflix at the same time - something's got to give! Only instead of your Wi-Fi crashing, your ceiling fan stops spinning, and your phone battery starts looking real sad.

normalised: Why does this happen, you ask? Well, India's electricity demand is constantly growing. We have more A C's, more factories churning out stuff, more people charging their phones (and watching cat videos, let's be honest). Sometimes, the power plants just can't keep up, especially older ones. And during peak seasons, like around Diwali when everyone's got their fairy lights blazing and the mithai shops are working overtime, the grid gets seriously stressed.

normalised: Think about it: millions of people across Uttar Pradesh switching on their geysers at the same time. That's a lot of electricity!

normalised: Load shedding used to be a HUGE problem, impacting businesses and households alike. Remember the days when you couldn't even watch your favorite cricket match uninterrupted because the power would cut out mid-over? Ugh, the horror! We've come a long way from there, but it still pops up, especially in smaller towns and rural areas.

normalised: Sometimes you'll see it announced in advance: "Load shedding scheduled for Sector fifteen tomorrow from two P M to four P M." Other times, it's a surprise power cut that leaves you sweating and wondering if your biryani will get cold before it's done.

normalised: The government and utility companies (like Tata Power or B S E S in Delhi) are working on it, of course. They're investing in renewable energy (solar power is becoming pretty big!), upgrading the grid, and trying to predict demand better. They're even rolling out smart grids that can automatically reroute power to where it's needed most. It's a slow process, but things are improving.
